For a triangle-free graph $G$ let $h_2(G)$ be the smallest number of edges that need to be added to $G$ so that it has diameter $2$ and is still triangle-free. Is it true that if $G$ has maximum degree $o(n^{1/2})$ then $h(G)=o(n^2)$?



A problem of Erd\H{o}s, Gy\'{a}rf\'{a}s, and Ruszink\'{o} \cite{EGR98}. Simonovits showed that there exist graphs $G$ with maximum degree $\gg n^{1/2}$ and $h_2(G)\gg n^2$.

Erd\H{o}s, Gy\'{a}rf\'{a}s, and Ruszink\'{o} \cite{EGR98} proved that if $G$ has no isolated vertices and maximum degree $O(1)$ then $h_2(G)\ll n\log n$.

Alon has observed this problem is essentially identical to [134], and his solution in this note also solves this problem in the affirmative.

See also [619].




References


[EGR98] Erd\H{o}s, Paul and Gy\'{a}rf\'{a}s, Andr\'{a}s and
Ruszink\'{o}, Mikl\'{o}s, How to decrease the diameter of triangle-free graphs. Combinatorica (1998), 493-501.
